reviewText: This is a must for every family member!  Have a spoiled child? What about a spoiled spouse?  This movie can be an eye-opener.  Life is hard.  Life isn't always fair.  But Liz reminds us that we are NEVER stuck within our circumstances and that it's a priveledge to have good parents, a wonderful family, a nice place to live, etc. etc.  This was a heartwarming film worthy of the praise it's received.

reviewText: I was riveted to this story from a magazine blurb directing me to watch this Lifetime movie that particular night which I knew was sanitized to pass for general consumption.(They were right to do so) It certainly whetted my curiosity to read her personal memoir(Breaking Night) of her lonely ascent through squalor to adulthood too. This is a story that should be spread to all the schools in the country who are experiencing the collapse of the education infrastructure. It should especially serve as a blueprint to those kids who feel abandoned by the public school system and would rather skip school. What Liz Murray does is so psychologically exceptional, going beyond the biographies of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln, great men too, who removed their shackles through autodidacticism, i.e. self-direction and self-development, and because of that singularity it should be on every child's book list along with Harry Potter. Books will create new avenues for you that only lead upward.
summary: A Child Breaks Free Of Her Own Boundaries
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are moments in this movie so rife with raw, emotional pain it makes it hard to sit thru. But maybe it's what makes HOMELESS TO HARVARD: THE LIZ MURRAY STORY an ideal holiday movie. Ultimately, it inspires and lends hope and perhaps makes you believe in miracles. It'll definitely make you believe in the value of perseverence and great effort. When you start feeling sorry for yourself, think about what Liz Murray went thru. And then get over yourself. This is a true story.Liz Murray, child of extreme poverty, victim of neglect by her drug-addicted parents, at age fifteen became homeless in New York City. HOMELESS TO HARVARD, which first aired in 2003 on the Lifetime channel, is a searing biopic. It pulls absolutely no punches in recounting Liz's harrowing years as she fought to survive on the streets. There are glimmers. Liz, when still with her parents, rarely attended school and all the time felt alienated in class. Didn't help that her classmates made fun of her as the smelly girl. And yet she consistently scored well on the few tests she took. So we're clued in to Liz's innate intelligence and her potential. Her tools for success, while gathering dust, had always been there.It's a terrific cast, with a particular nod to Kelly Lynch, superb and harrowing as Liz's hopelessly addicted mother. Thora Birch is so very good here. She underplays it, and yet she gives you the layers underneath. You're allowed a peek into her character's feelings of desolation and worthlessness and fright. It's devastating stuff. You can't help but cheer when the turning point comes around, when Liz Murray at last decides to pick herself up. So Liz begins to attend high school and to immediately excel. How amazing is it that she graduated in just two freakin' years? She eyes an essay competition sponsored by the New York Times, the prize of which is a paid scholarship to Harvard. Because when Liz Murray finally decided to dream, she dreamed big. It's the only way to do it.This movie is riveting and heartbreaking and, at times, quite hard to watch. And maybe now it'll give you pause when you glance at the homeless, runaway, disenfranchised youths who roam the streets (and maybe it won't). Liz Murray's improbable story demonstrates that one CAN escape the shackles of a nightmarish upbringing. It's not a coincidence that HOMELESS TO HARVARD was part of television programming over the holidays. Yeah, it's fun to observe tradition by watching Santa Claus and elves and flying reindeer. But nothing beats a real miracle story.
summary: ...Homeless to Harvard - how Liz reached safe harbor...

reviewText: I saw this one when it first came out (on Lifetime) and am delighted it is finally available on video/Dvd. Thora Birch does an exceptional job playing a girl whose family life is chaotic (her mother is a drug addict, her father is mentally ill).She's the butt of jokes at school because she has had no training in normal social behanvior and her home is so cluttered and messy that finding clean clothes to wear is a major challenge.Somehow she manages to rise above her circumstances, beating the odds and going to Harvard. Credit the filmmakers for being honest and staying away from saccharine solutions. THis is a gritty but riveting film. A must-have in my colletion..should be in yours.
summary: True tale of homeless girl who made it to Harvard

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: The first time my wife watched this movie I passed it by because I usually find these types of movies cheesy.  However, after hearing my wife and daughter both comment on how good the movie was, I decided to give it a chance and convinced them to watch it again.  As it turns out, they both liked it enough that they stayed glued to the television for a second time.Thora Birch (who is already a veteran actor with roles in movies like "American Beauty," "Alaska," and "Patriot Games") plays Liz Murray.  Liz and her sister are tossed on a stormy and bizarre sea of life as their parents both have drug abuse problems, and their mother is a schizophrenic as well.  Liz somehow manages to keep it together as their mother Jean (Kelley Lynch) is put into a mental institution, and then returns with the bad news that she has AIDS.  I found the scenes where her mother dies to be poignant without the sort of treacle sweet nonsense that many made-for-tv movies try to use in place of good acting.In most cases a young lady like Liz Murray would have dropped out of school and had issues of her own.  Instead, she fights to get into Harvard, and overcomes the odds to succeed.  Usually I would get into extensive detail about how she does that, but the movie is excellently plotted and paced, so you may learn for yourself how Liz manages to overcome her lack of social skills and poor wardrobe to impress others enough to gain a scholarship.A secondary issue is the veracity of the movie.  I had a couple of long discussions about "A Beautiful Mind" with people who had read the book because of the movie's inaccuracies.  However, just as in that movie, I liked this movie because it portrayed someone that conquered life's adversities in a very deliberate fashion, making decisions that bring out a powerful emotional response (in me, anyway).  Just because there are problems with the accuracy of either movie does not lessen the effect of the movie on a viewer.  It is true (as of the writing of this review) that Liz did drop out of Harvard, and now makes a living as an inspirational speaker.  However, while she did not complete Harvard, the fact that she was able to overcome her terrible background to become what she is today should still be an inspiration.Watch the movie for content of the movie and the wonderful job Thora Birch did as Liz Murray.  Everything else is secondary.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd been directed to this movie by a friend, so had seen it before I bought my own copy.  The heroine in this story proves that nothing can hold back someone who has gumption and will, though she didn't believe in herself at first.  Her background was so negative that she had to learn to disassociate herself from it in order to see hope.  Yet she didn't lose her caring for those with whom she'd lived growing up.
summary: One of the truly inspiring stories of overcoming horrendous odds to achieve

reviewText: This was a short and sweet true story and I was surprised I liked it for one it's a made for tv movie by lifetime so right of the bat it didn't have much going for it. However it turned out to be a great story about a girl who beats all odds of a broken home. After becoming a parent myself I was quite angry with the parents in this story but then again I have never battled an addiction,schizophrenia or poverty of that level..I am by far not the perfect parent.
summary: Great Story!  Oprah check this out it's true!

reviewText: Its a sob story. Anyone can be a drug addict, or a criminal, or an illegal immigrant, and really suffer for it. But even felons and people who are dying of diseases get jobs or live out a somewhat meaningful life in service to others. Her parents want to party and play the system and use drugs all the time. And cry into their coffees. Its pretty suspicious. I wonder if her parents were college educated themselves.Yeah, losing her mom is sad. You feel bad about that. But not really the rest.What's the point of this? Lizzy thinks she should be a good girl, and go to school? Who cares? A lot of people who don't go to school still make money and get good jobs. She just miraculously gets all the answers right on the tests? Please. Its like, this is my glowing story about how tough my life was and how wonderful things turned out anyway...because I chose *school.* We're all forced into school, most of us realize what a soul-murdering place it is anyway. School makes you great? How? Why are there so many movies about how *school* saves teenagers? Why couldn't she find her strength somewhere else? Why school? This sounds like a white version of the movie "Precious."Does this person "Liz," actually ever have any kind of job today, or does she just make a living talking about her hardships? A "degree" does not magically make you sucessful or give you a happy ending! What makes a person happy and sucessful are things like good friends, and an ability to adapt to change. A lot of college grads are out sweeping floors and making lattes. Some are jobless and hopeless. Maybe some of the other Harvard grads will write a different movie called "From Harvard to Homeless."
summary: I just don't get the point of this movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: Liz Murray was raised in poverty by drug-addicted parents. Though they loved her, they were unable to care for her and Liz ended up living on the streets by the age of 15.Profoundly affected by her mother's AIDS-related death, Liz forced herself to look at her future and make some significant changes. Her prospects were dismal, yet she turned her life around by going back to high school. After earning her diploma in just 2 years, while still homeless, Liz won a New York Times scholarship for needy students, which enabled her to attend Harvard University.
summary: Like A Rags To Riches Kind Of Movie
Title: N/A
